title: 105_hr3032
content: The Act titled "Construction Subcontractors Payment Protection Enhancement Act of 1998" and outlines additional responsibilities for the Administrator for Federal Procurement Policy. The Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act is amended to establish Government-wide policies for timely payment of contractors, subcontractors, and suppliers. This includes implementing statutes like the Prompt Payment Act, the Miller Act, and the Federal Acquisition Streamlining Act of 1994. The Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act is amended to establish Government-wide policies for timely payment of contractors, subcontractors, and suppliers. Proposed revisions to the Government-wide Federal Acquisition Regulation must be published within 120 days of enactment, with final regulations to be effective within 30 days of publication. Additionally, related amendments to the Miller Act are included. The Miller Act is being amended to improve payment bond protection by equalizing the amount of the payment bond to the performance bond, extending protection to all subcontractors and suppliers, and specifying conditions for progress payments. The Miller Act is amended to extend payment bond protection to all subcontractors and suppliers, specifying conditions for progress payments. The Miller Act is amended to require notice of a suit to the contractor within 90 days. Additionally, no waiver of payment bond protection is valid unless in writing after the right to sue is established. Service of payment bond claims is modernized to allow delivery to the contractor at any business location. The Miller Act is amended to require notice of a suit to the contractor within 90 days and modernize service of payment bond claims by allowing delivery through various means. The Miller Act is amended to allow suits to proceed even if filed within 90 days of the last labor or material supplied, as long as the contractor denies payment in writing. Additionally, courts may award court costs, attorneys' fees, and interest to the prevailing party in frivolous or groundless suits. The Miller Act allows for court awards of interest, calculated from the claim date to payment date using applicable interest rates, to preserve Act protections for small claims. Contracting officers' accountability under the Act is further emphasized. The Miller Act emphasizes the accountability of contracting officers in ensuring payment bonds are obtained and remain in effect during the contract administration. Failure to fulfill these responsibilities may result in court authorization for a person to bring suit if the required payment bond is not in effect. The Miller Act holds contracting officers accountable for ensuring payment bonds are in effect. If the officer fails in their responsibilities, the court may authorize a person to sue the United States for the amount they would have sued for under section 2.
